title: 103_hr929
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SIMPLIFICATION OF EMPLOYMENT TAXES ON DOMESTIC SERVICES." is about simplifying employment taxes related to domestic services. Increase in Threshold Requirement for wages and Social Security Act to $300. Coordination of Collection of Domestic Service Employment with Income Taxes under Chapter 25 of the Internal Revenue Code. The Social Security Act is amended to increase the threshold requirement for wages to $300. Additionally, coordination of the collection of domestic service employment with income taxes is addressed in Chapter 25 of the Internal Revenue Code. SEC. 3510 addresses the coordination of collecting domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. SEC. 3510 states that returns for domestic service employment taxes are filed on a calendar year basis, due by the 15th day of the fourth month after the employer's taxable year, with no deposit requirements. Domestic service employment taxes are subject to estimated tax provisions for section 6654. For domestic service employment taxes, no deposit requirements apply for the employer's taxable year, and these taxes are subject to estimated tax provisions under section 6654. Provisions state that domestic service employment taxes are treated as a tax imposed by chapter 2 for the employer's taxable year. Adjustments may be made in the application of section 6654(d)(2) under regulations. A transitional rule applies for the taxable year beginning in 1994. The transitional rule for the taxable year beginning in 1994 increases the amount referred to in section 6654(d)(1)(B) by 90 percent of the tax treated under paragraph (1). The term 'domestic service employment taxes' refers to taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home and amounts withheld under section 3402(p). The term 'domestic service in a private home of the employer' excludes certain services under section 3121(g)(5). This section may not apply to employers liable for other employment taxes as per regulations by the Secretary. The term 'domestic service in a private home of the employer' excludes certain services under section 3121(g)(5). This section may not apply to employers liable for other employment taxes as per regulations by the Secretary. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for carrying out the purposes of this section. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for remuneration for services other than domestic service in a private home of the employer. Additionally, the Secretary is authorized to enter into agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes. The Secretary is authorized to enter into agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home of the employer. The Secretary can enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home of the employer. Any taxes collected will be treated as domestic service employment taxes and transferred to the state's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Any amount collected under an agreement shall be transferred to the State's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund and treated as a tax imposed by chapter 23. The term 'State' is defined as per section 3306(j)(1). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 25. The paragraph is treated as a tax under chapter 23. The amendments made by this section apply to remuneration paid in calendar years after 1993.
